title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Probability Theory
text:
Imagine you are a project manager assessing the probability of a project being delivered on time based on the occurrence of a change in scope. The following probabilities have been determined using historical project data:
Assume P(T) as probability of project being done on time and P(S) as probability of change of scope of project.

Probability of a change in scope, 
P(S) = 0.3 \\
P(\bar S) =  0.7

Probability of completing/not completing the project on time, given the change in scope, 
  P(T \mid S) = 0.2 \\
  P(\bar T \mid S) = 0.8 \\
  P(T \mid \bar S) = 0.6 \\
  P(\bar T \mid \bar S) = 0.4 \\




Compute the following probabilities and the sum of all four probabilities: 
P(T \cap S) \\
P(\bar T \cap S) \\
P(T \cap \bar S) \\
P(\bar T \cap \bar S) \\







# Assign probabilities of events T and S
prob_S <- 0.3
prob_S_T <- 0.2
prob_S_Tbar <- 0.8

prob_Sbar <- 0.7
prob_Sbar_T <- 0.6
prob_Sbar_Tbar <- 0.4

# Calculate P(T ∩ S)
prob_T_and_S <- prob_S_T * prob_S

# Calculate P(T ∩ S_bar)
prob_T_and_S_bar <- prob_Sbar_T * prob_Sbar

# Calculate P(T_bar ∩ S)
prob_not_T_and_S <- prob_S_Tbar * prob_S

# Calculate P(T_bar ∩ S_bar)
prob_not_T_and_not_S <- prob_Sbar_Tbar * prob_Sbar

# Sum of all probalilities
sum <- prob_T_and_S + prob_T_and_S_bar + prob_not_T_and_S + prob_not_T_and_not_S

# Print the results
prob_T_and_S

#> [1] 0.06

prob_T_and_S_bar

#> [1] 0.42

prob_not_T_and_S

#> [1] 0.24

prob_not_T_and_not_S

#> [1] 0.28

sum

#> [1] 1


The provided R code calculates the probabilities of different events based on the given probabilities for a project being delivered on time, considering the occurrence of a change in scope. The results are printed, including the probabilities of the project being delivered on time with and without a change in scope, and the sum of all four probabilities.

title: Probability Theory
text:
1 Project - Assignment I
Imagine you are a project manager assessing the probability of a project being delivered on time based on the occurrence of a change in scope. The following probabilities have been determined using historical project data:

Probability of a change in scope, \[P(S) = 0.3\]
If there is a change in scope, ( P(T | S) = 0.2 )
If there is no change in scope, ( P(T | S) = 0.6 )

Define the following events: - ( T ): Project delivered on time - ( T_{} ): Project not delivered on time - ( S ): Change in scope - ( S_{} ): No change in scope
Compute the following probabilities and the sum of all four probabilities:

( P(T S) )
( P(T_{} S) )
( P(T S_{}) )
( P(T_{} S_{}) )

# Assign probabilities of events T and S
prob_S <- 0.3
prob_S_T <- 0.2
prob_S_Tbar <- 0.8

prob_Sbar <- 0.7
prob_Sbar_T <- 0.6
prob_Sbar_Tbar <- 0.4

# Calculate P(T ∩ S)
prob_T_and_S <- prob_S_T * prob_S

# Calculate P(T ∩ S_bar)
prob_T_and_S_bar <- prob_Sbar_T * prob_Sbar

# Calculate P(T_bar ∩ S)
prob_not_T_and_S <- prob_S_Tbar * prob_S

# Calculate P(T_bar ∩ S_bar)
prob_not_T_and_not_S <- prob_Sbar_Tbar * prob_Sbar

# Sum of all probalilities
sum <- prob_T_and_S + prob_T_and_S_bar + prob_not_T_and_S + prob_not_T_and_not_S

# Print the results
cat("P(T ∩ S):", prob_T_and_S, "\n")
cat("P(T ∩ S'):", prob_T_and_S_bar, "\n")
cat("P(T' ∩ S):", prob_not_T_and_S, "\n")
cat("P(T' ∩ S'): ", prob_not_T_and_not_S, "\n")
cat("Sum :", sum, "\n")
The provided R code calculates the probabilities of different events based on the given probabilities for a project being delivered on time, considering the occurrence of a change in scope. The results are printed, including the probabilities of the project being delivered on time with and without a change in scope, and the sum of all four probabilities.

title: Probability Theory
text:
Imagine you are a project manager assessing the probability of a project being delivered on time based on the occurrence of a change in scope. The following probabilities have been determined using historical project data:
Assume P(T) as probability of project being done on time and P(S) as probability of change of scope of project.

Probability of a change in scope, \[
P(S) = 0.3 \\
P(\bar S) =  0.7
\]
Probability of completing/not completing the project on time, given the change in scope, \[
  P(T \mid S) = 0.2 \\
  P(\bar T \mid S) = 0.8 \\
  P(T \mid \bar S) = 0.6 \\
  P(\bar T \mid \bar S) = 0.4 \\
\]

title: Probability Theory
text:
Compute the following probabilities and the sum of all four probabilities: 
P(T \cap S) \\
P(\bar T \cap S) \\
P(T \cap \bar S) \\
P(\bar T \cap \bar S) \\

title: Probability Theory
text:
# Assign probabilities of events T and S
prob_S <- 0.3
prob_S_T <- 0.2
prob_S_Tbar <- 0.8

prob_Sbar <- 0.7
prob_Sbar_T <- 0.6
prob_Sbar_Tbar <- 0.4

# Calculate P(T ∩ S)
prob_T_and_S <- prob_S_T * prob_S

# Calculate P(T ∩ S_bar)
prob_T_and_S_bar <- prob_Sbar_T * prob_Sbar

# Calculate P(T_bar ∩ S)
prob_not_T_and_S <- prob_S_Tbar * prob_S

# Calculate P(T_bar ∩ S_bar)
prob_not_T_and_not_S <- prob_Sbar_Tbar * prob_Sbar

# Sum of all probalilities
sum <- prob_T_and_S + prob_T_and_S_bar + prob_not_T_and_S + prob_not_T_and_not_S

# Print the results
prob_T_and_S

#> [1] 0.06

prob_T_and_S_bar

#> [1] 0.42

prob_not_T_and_S

#> [1] 0.24

prob_not_T_and_not_S

#> [1] 0.28

sum

#> [1] 1


The provided R code calculates the probabilities of different events based on the given probabilities for a project being delivered on time, considering the occurrence of a change in scope. The results are printed, including the probabilities of the project being delivered on time with and without a change in scope, and the sum of all four probabilities.
